Less aggressive than 6. Bc4 or Bg5, but perfectly playable.

I play the Boleslavsky variation. http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessopening?eco=B59 Black puts up with a backward d pawn on a semi-open file, and a weak d5 square in return for time and counter-attacking opportunities.
I think this is a mistake, as at a stroke, after the pawn recapture, black hasn't a weak d5 square any more and after prearation can normally play d6-d5, and have a good centre.
Both sides have made natural developing moves. White's best is now Kh1 or f4, hitting black's pawn centre before he gets the chance of advancing in the centre.

This looks like another mistake to me, blocking his f pawn. Without advancing his f pawn how is he going to attack?
besides he can't hold back d6-d5 for long.

But I get in first. We are following src36 (1717) vs. the_caboose (2271). http://gameknot.com/analyze-board.pl?bd=23041491&fb=1&mv=20&rnd=0.417476317219698
In that game white makes the mistake of exchanging on d5. My opponent finds a better way.
